plastic_recycling.title: Comprehensive Plastic Recycling Guide
plastic_recycling.content:
Plastic recycling codes 1-7 explained:

#1 PET (Polyethylene Terephthalate): Water bottles, soda bottles, food containers. RECYCLABLE in most programs.

#2 HDPE (High-Density Polyethylene): Milk jugs, detergent bottles, shampoo bottles. HIGHLY RECYCLABLE.

#3 PVC (Polyvinyl Chloride): Pipes, vinyl siding, some packaging. RARELY RECYCLABLE - check locally.

#4 LDPE (Low-Density Polyethylene): Plastic bags, squeeze bottles, bread bags. SOMETIMES RECYCLABLE - often requires special drop-off.

#5 PP (Polypropylene): Yogurt containers, bottle caps, straws. INCREASINGLY RECYCLABLE.

#6 PS (Polystyrene): Foam cups, takeout containers, packing peanuts. RARELY RECYCLABLE - avoid when possible.

#7 Other: Mixed plastics, bioplastics. USUALLY NOT RECYCLABLE - varies by facility.

Best practices: Rinse containers, remove labels when possible, check local guidelines, never bag recyclables in plastic bags.

composting_guide.title: Complete Composting Guide
composting_guide.content:
Composting transforms organic waste into nutrient-rich soil amendment.

GREEN MATERIALS (Nitrogen-rich):
- Fruit and vegetable scraps
- Coffee grounds and filters
- Tea bags (remove staples)
- Grass clippings
- Fresh plant trimmings
- Eggshells (crushed)
- Seaweed and kelp

BROWN MATERIALS (Carbon-rich):
- Dry leaves
- Straw and hay
- Wood chips and sawdust (untreated)
- Shredded newspaper
- Cardboard (torn into pieces)
- Paper towels and napkins
- Dryer lint (natural fibers only)

NEVER COMPOST:
- Meat, fish, bones
- Dairy products
- Oils and fats
- Pet waste
- Diseased plants
- Weeds with seeds
- Treated wood
- Glossy paper

COMPOSTING METHODS:
1. Hot composting: Active management, 3-6 months
2. Cold composting: Passive, 6-12 months
3. Vermicomposting: Using worms, 2-3 months
4. Bokashi: Fermentation method, 2-4 weeks

Optimal conditions: 3:1 brown to green ratio, moisture like wrung-out sponge, turn every 2-3 weeks, maintain 135-160Â°F for hot composting.

e_waste_disposal.title: Electronic Waste Disposal Guide
e_waste_disposal.content:
E-waste contains valuable materials and toxic substances requiring special handling.

COMMON E-WASTE:
- Computers and laptops
- Smartphones and tablets
- TVs and monitors
- Printers and scanners
- Batteries (all types)
- Cables and chargers
- Small appliances
- Gaming consoles

WHY SPECIAL HANDLING:
- Contains precious metals: gold, silver, copper, platinum
- Contains toxic materials: lead, mercury, cadmium, beryllium
- Data security concerns
- Environmental contamination risk

DISPOSAL OPTIONS:
1. Manufacturer take-back programs (Apple, Dell, HP, etc.)
2. Retailer recycling (Best Buy, Staples)
3. Municipal e-waste collection events
4. Certified e-waste recyclers (e-Stewards, R2 certified)
5. Donation to schools or nonprofits (if functional)

BEFORE RECYCLING:
- Back up important data
- Perform factory reset
- Remove SIM cards and memory cards
- Remove batteries if possible

NEVER: Throw e-waste in regular trash or recycling bins.

hazardous_waste.title: Hazardous Waste Disposal
hazardous_waste.content:
Household hazardous waste requires special disposal to protect health and environment.

COMMON HAZARDOUS WASTE:
- Paints and solvents
- Motor oil and antifreeze
- Pesticides and herbicides
- Cleaning chemicals
- Batteries (car, rechargeable)
- Fluorescent bulbs and CFLs
- Thermometers and thermostats (mercury)
- Propane tanks

DISPOSAL METHODS:
1. Household Hazardous Waste (HHW) collection facilities
2. Special collection events
3. Retailer take-back programs
4. Auto parts stores (for automotive fluids)
5. Battery recycling programs

SAFETY TIPS:
- Keep in original containers
- Never mix chemicals
- Transport upright and secure
- Bring during daylight hours
- Follow facility guidelines

ALTERNATIVES:
- Use up products completely
- Share with neighbors
- Choose eco-friendly alternatives
- Buy only what you need

textile_recycling.title: Textile and Clothing Recycling
textile_recycling.content:
Textile waste is a growing environmental concern. Most textiles are recyclable or reusable.

WHAT CAN BE RECYCLED:
- Clothing (any condition)
- Shoes and accessories
- Linens and towels
- Curtains and drapes
- Fabric scraps

DISPOSAL OPTIONS:
1. DONATE (good condition):
   - Goodwill, Salvation Army
   - Local shelters
   - Dress for Success
   - Vietnam Veterans of America

2. RECYCLE (worn/damaged):
   - H&M garment collection
   - North Face Clothes the Loop
   - Patagonia Worn Wear
   - Textile recycling bins

3. UPCYCLE:
   - Cut into cleaning rags
   - Craft projects
   - Pet bedding
   - Insulation material

ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT:
- 85% of textiles end up in landfills
- Takes 200+ years to decompose
- Textile production uses massive water and energy
- Fast fashion creates 92 million tons of waste annually

SUSTAINABLE CHOICES:
- Buy quality over quantity
- Choose natural fibers
- Support sustainable brands
- Repair and mend clothing
- Shop secondhand

ocean_plastic.title: Ocean Plastic Pollution Crisis
ocean_plastic.content: 8 million metric tons of plastic enter oceans annually. By 2050, oceans may contain more plastic than fish by weight. 5 trillion plastic pieces currently float in oceans. Great Pacific Garbage Patch is twice the size of Texas. Microplastics found in 90% of seabirds, 100% of sea turtles. Plastic kills 1 million seabirds and 100,000 marine mammals yearly. Solutions: Reduce single-use plastics, support ocean cleanup initiatives, proper waste disposal, beach cleanups.

climate_impact.title: Waste and Climate Change
climate_impact.content: Landfills produce 15% of US methane emissions. Methane is 25x more potent than CO2 as greenhouse gas. Recycling reduces emissions by 35% compared to landfilling. Composting organic waste prevents methane generation. Manufacturing from recycled materials uses 30-90% less energy. One ton of recycled paper saves 17 trees, 7,000 gallons of water, 3 cubic yards of landfill space, 2 barrels of oil, 4,100 kWh of electricity.
